column4: that IPv6 link did help a bit with FireFox (15s connect time vs. 35s before) but didn't help for example using system update
your ISP's DNS servers might be a bit slow today... look up another DNS server and try that
don't think it's DNS related problem because my other PC isn't slow at all and different days do not matter either
ok, one point to rule out then
and be aware that ubuntus quickly rising popularity causes some mirrors to be slow at times... the infrastructure can't keep up with the speed of usernumber increase
Ah, yeah, but the problem does appear downloading from local http servers which are working at maximum speed on my other PC
I'm sorry I accidentally turned FF IPv6 option back on as I had week ago turned it off. Network seems to be working as fast as it can on this mighty old Pentium :D Big thanks
Don't know, how I'll check it ?
they are disabled by default. What machine (cpu/memory/graphics) do you have there?
AMD Athlon64 3800+ / Kingston 2Gb 400Mhz RAM / ATI Radeon X850XT
what does glxinfo | grep direct tell? (use pastebin if there's more than 2 lines of output
does glxinfo | grep Mesa give anythin?
does glxinfo | grep Mesa give anythin?
OpenGL renderer string: Mesa DRI R300 20060815 x86/MMX+/3DNow!+/SSE2 TCL and on 2nd line OpenGL version string: 1.3 Mesa 6.5.2
i think your 3D acceleration isn't set up properly. You are using software emulation for 3D this is waht makes things so sluggish
i'm no ati expert, but getting ati cards to work properly can be a bit of pain
OK then I need to find a way to get card in operation. Thank you for this. I'll try that link
